ECEnumeration.description: Set the shape of a gravity structure.
Set the shape of a pipe element.

ECEnumerator.name: Rect_Chamfers3_4In_NonOffsetWingwallFlares45Deg_SkewedBarrel30Deg
ECEnumerator.displayLabel: 3/4" chamfers; 18.4° non-offset wingwall flares; 30° skewed barrel

ECEnumerator.name: Transition
ECEnumerator.description: Headwall represents a transition between piped flow and channel flow or vice versa

ECEnumerator.name: PondInflow
ECEnumerator.description: The headwall empties into a pond.

ECEnumerator.name: PondOutflow
ECEnumerator.description: Headwall works as a pond drain.

ECEnumerator.name: AsOutfall
ECEnumerator.description: Headwall acts as boundary outfall to a network.

ECEnumerator.name: Simple
ECEnumerator.description: The user enters in a single value for the Tc.

ECEnumerator.name: FlowPath
ECEnumerator.description: The time of concentration is calculated along the flow path.

ECEntityClass.description: Model containing all Sewer Hydraulic Analysis elements.
Specializied Sewer Hydraulics perspective in the hierarchy

ECRelationshipClass.description: Relates a SewerHydraulicAnalysisModel to the SewerHydraulicAnalysisPartition that it sub-models.

ECProperty.description: Specify the runoff method to be used by all catchments
Specify the infiltration method to calculate runoff when not using the Rational Method.
The minimum velocity constraint used during constraint based design.
The maximum velocity constraint used during constraint based design.
The minimum allowable cover during the constraint based design.
The maximum allowable cover during the constraint based design.
Specify how cover is measured during the design.
The minimum slope allowable during the constraint based design.
The maximum slope allowable during the constraint based design.
If true, design the pipe so the depth of flow is a percentage of the conduit's rise.
Specify the percent of depth for calculating design capacity.
If true the design can add pipe capacity by adding additional pipes.
Will restrict the number of barrels to this value, if multiple barrels are allowed.
If true, then the design will restrict the size of pipe to the 'Rise (Maximum)' attribute.
The maximum allowable pipe size to be used during the constraint based design.
Set the offset distance between the upstream and downstream conduits.

In some situations, drop structures can minimize pipe cover depths while maintaining adequate hydraulic performance. This can be done by setting this field to true and performing a constraint based design.

ECProperty.displayLabel: Use Drop Structure to Minimize Cover
ECProperty.description: When this field and Allow Drop Structure are set to true, node drop structure is designed even if the node upstream pipe slope is smaller than maximum slope in design constraints.

Drop Depth is the difference between conduit invert when the drop structure is designed and the conduit invert when the drop structure is not designed. If the calculated drop depth is smaller than this value, the drop structure will not be designed.
Specify whether the matchline offset will be based on conduit inverts or conduit crowns.
Maximum width of flow allowed at capture for an In Sag inlet, or width of bypass flow for an On Grade inlet.
Maximum depth of flow allowed at capture for an In Sag inlet, or depth of bypass flow for an On Grade inlet.
Minimum allowable efficiency for an inlet on grade.
If true the subsurface structure will be designed to meet the active pipe matching constraints.
The minimum allowable cover at the node during the constraint based design.
The maximum allowable cover at the node during the constraint based design.
Distance between lowest pipe invert or pipe bottom (depending on calculation option setting), and the invert of the structure.
The depth below the rim elevation that is used to determine the lower limit of the overflow risk status during critical storm analysis.
Specify how to calculate headloss at the structure.
The headloss across the structure will be equal to this coefficient multiplied by the exit pipe velocity head.
The user defined headloss at the structure.
Restricts the direction of flow to the specified direction.
Set the coefficient of flow for the weir, which used to account for variables that are not otherwise directly accounted for in the weir equation (e.g., vena contracta).
Set the coefficient of flow for the orifice.
The elevation of the top of the riser.
The diameter of the opening at the top of the riser structure.
Specify the active weir length for the opening at the top of the box.
Specify the active orifice area for the top opening when inlet box is submerged
Coefficient of flow for the orifice.
Specify if the orifice oriented perpendicular or parallel to flow.
Specify the shape of the orifice
The diameter of the orifice opening
The area of the orifice opening.
The top of the orifice opening.
Set the elevation from which to measure the orifice head (H) when a perpendicular orifice orientation is specified.
Specify the shape of weir
Coefficient of flow for the rectangular weir.
Coefficient of flow for the v-notch weir.
If true then the SWMM engine will treat the manhole as a storage unit.
If true then the manhole can go under pressure.
Method used to determine the rate of flow capture by the inlet.
If true then the length of the inlet will be designed to meet the active inlet design constraints.
If true then the user can override the system wide design constraints for the current inlet.
The height of the gutter, over which overflow will occur.
The transverse slope of the road.
If true the gutter slope differs from the road cross slope.
Enter the horizontal width of the gutter. This is equal to the distance from the curb face to the point at which the gutter cross slope begins.
Enter the transverse slope of the gutter. This value is typically equal to or greater than the road cross slope.
Set the percent of incoming inflow to be captured by the inlet.
The inlet will capture all incoming flow up the specified threshold, all excess flow will be bypassed.
Choose if the inlet is on grade or in sag.
Choose the type of inlet structure.
Length of grate parallel to the gutter.
Length of grate perpendicular to the gutter.
Specify the type of grate to be used during the calculation.
Length of curb opening.
Size of the vertical opening of curb inlet.
Angle throat of the curb inlet relative to the horizontal. Is used when the throat type is inclined.
Specify orientation of curb throat relative to the horizontal.
Specify how the headwall be treated during a calculation.
Choose the headwall definition from which to perform inlet control calculations, or choose none to ignore.
Select method to establish bounding tailwater for the network.

ECNavigationProperty.description: Specify the element which the catchment outflows.

ECProperty.description: Select method to establish bounding tailwater for the network.
Set the invert of pipe adjacent to the start node.
Set the invert of the pipe adjacent to the stop node.
The roughness value for the pipe.
The horizontal length of the pipe.
Select the shape of the pipe.
Select the number of equal sized barrels of the pipe.
If true then the pipe will be designed during a design run.
If true then the start invert will be adjusted during the design.
If true then the stop invert will be adjusted during the design.
If true then you can override the design constraints for the current pipe.

ECNavigationProperty.description: Specify the element which the catchment outflows.

ECProperty.description: Specify the longest time it takes for flow to traverse the longest flow path on the catchment.
Choose how to generate the Time of Concentration for the catchment
The length of the flow travel path to use when calculating the Tc.
The average slope of the flow path to use when calculating the Tc.
The Manning's n of the flow travel path to use when calculating the Tc.
The depth 2 year 24 hour storm at the location.
If true will use the paved form of the TR-55 Shallow Concentrated Flow Tc formula.
Wetted Perimeter of flow in channel to be used in TR-55 Channel Flow Formula for Tc.
Area of flow in channel to be used in TR-55 Channel Flow Formula for Tc.
Specify how to define the area for the catchment
Specify the size of the catchment
The runoff coefficient used with the Rational Method. C in Q=CiA.

ECStructArrayProperty.description: The list of subareas that comprise the total area of the catchment. The weighted average of the rational c value will be used to compute the runoff.

ECStructClass.description: The list of subareas that comprise the total area of the catchment. The weighted average of the rational c value will be used to compute the runoff.

ECProperty.description: The size of the subarea.
The Rational C coefficient to be applied to the current subarea.

The width of the overland flow path for sheet flow runoff (note: the catchment area occupied by Low Impact Development Controls (if any) should not be considered when determining characteristic width).
Average slope of the catchment.
Manning's n for overland flow over the impervious portion of the catchment.
Manning's n for overland flow over the pervious portion of the catchment.
Depth of depression storage on the impervious portion of the catchment.
Depth of depression storage on the pervious portion of the catchment.
Percent of land area (not including any land in this catchment associated with a Low Impact Development Control) that is impervious.
Percent of the impervious area with no depression storage.
Choice of internal routing of runoff between pervious and impervious areas.

ECStructArrayProperty.description: The list of subareas that comprise the total area of the catchment. The weighted average of the CN value will be used to compute the runoff.

ECStructClass.description: The list of subareas that comprise the total area of the catchment. The weighted average of the CN value will be used to compute the runoff.

ECProperty.description: Curve Number value to use by the SCS Infiltration method to define the characteristics of land surface of the catchment.
The equilibrium infiltration rate on the Horton infiltration curve reached once the soil becomes saturated.
The initial or maximum infiltration rate on Horton infiltration curve.
Decay constant associated with the soil.
The initial abstraction accounts for all losses prior to runoff and consists mainly of interception, infiltration, evaporation, and surface depression storage.
Maximum infiltration volume possible (0 if not applicable). Can be estimated as the difference between a soil's porosity and its wilting point times the depth of the infiltration zone.
Fraction of soil volume that is initially dry (i.e., difference between soil porosity and initial moisture content).
Average value of soil capillary suction along the wetting front.
The saturated hydraulic conductivity for this catchment (the rate at which water travels through the soil when it is saturated).
Set water surface elevation in the pond at the beginning of the simulation.

ECStructArrayProperty.description: Define the volume of the pond using a stage-area curve.

ECProperty.description: Specify how to define the rainfall data for this rainfall set.
Choose the design storm to apply to this rainfall set.
Duration of storm
Intensity at duration
Choose the hydraulics engine to calculate the current site.
The overall invert elevation of the storage chamber system (i.e. the bottom of the base fill).
The number of rows of the selected storage chamber.
The number of storae chambers per row.
The void space of fill/stone that surround the storage chambers.
The edge to edge spacing between the rows of storage chambers.
The distance between edges of the storage chambers and the side of the surrounding fill.
The distance between the top of the fill and the top of the storage chambers.
The distance from the bottom of the fill to the bottom of the storage chambers.
The side slope of the fill on all four sides.
The distance between ends of the storage chambers and the end of the surrounding fill.
Choose how to define the shape of the storage chamber
The length of the storage chamber when it is interlocked in a storage chamber row. If the Section Length Varies, then the effective length represent the length of the middle sections.
Adjusts the internal storage volume of the storage chamber.
Set the default edge to edge spacing for the storage chamber when organized into rows on the Pond Element.
If true then the user can specify the effective lengths of the start and stop sections of a Storage Chamber row.
Specify the length of the storage chamber at the start of the Storage Chamber row.
Specify the length of the storage chamber at the end of the Storage Chamber row.
Average wall thickness of the storage chamber.
The internal diameter of the circular structure.
The vertical internal opening height of the storage chamber.
The horizontal internal opening height of the storage chamber.

ECStructClass.description: The Depth-Width Curve point for a storage chamber

ECProperty.description: Depth measured from the bottom of the storage chamber.
Width of the inner chamber opening.
Total width of the chamber including the wall thickiness
The maximum span that occurs in the structure. This is used for setting the spacing in the Storage Chamber System.

ECStructArrayProperty.displayLabel: Depth-Incremental Volume Per Unit Length Curve

ECProperty.description: Depth measured from the bottom of the storage chamber.
The incremental volume per length at the current depth.
The internal full area of the structure.
The internal bottom radius of the Pipe Arch Structure.
The internal Corner Radius of the structure.
The internal Bottom Distance of the Pipe Arch.
The internal Top Radius of the Pipe Arch.
Select the type of calculation to perform
The minimum allowed time of concentration on on a catchment.
If True, the system travel time in the pipe will be the Minimum for Time of Concentration or greater.
Maximum number of iterations that will be performed to achieve the closest approximation of the desired network results.
Value is taken as the maximum relative change in discharge occurring at the system outlet between two successive network solutions.
Select how the engine performs flow routing.
The gradually varied flow profile divides each pipe into internal segments (profile steps) prior to calculation of the hydraulic grade.
In full network calculation this value is taken as the maximum absolute change between two successive solves of hydraulic grade at any junction or inlet in the system.
The method used to calculate the average travel time velocity.
If the system calculates a structure headloss that is lower then this value, the value specified will be used.
Specify the basis for the hydraulic calculations.

ECProperty.displayLabel: Ignore Pipe Travel Time in Carrier Pipes
ECProperty.description: Ignore the travel time in carrier pipes (pipes with no subcatchment connected to their upstream node) when computing system time at the node immediately downstream of the carrier pipe.

If false, the simulation will always adopt the largest system time from all incoming flows. Otherwise, when two or more rational flows enter a single node, StormCAD will adopt the system time that produces the largest rational flow. A larger 'partial area' flow will be carried downstream until the 'total area' flows exceeds it.
The method to use to route flows through the conveyance system: Uniform Flow, Kinematic Wave, or Dynamic Wave.

Lets you select whether or not to allow excess water to collect at gravity structures and be re-introduced into the system as conditions permit. In order for ponding to actually occur at a particular node, you must enter a non-zero value for the node's Ponded Area attribute.

The time step used for routing flows and water quality constituents through the conveyance system. Note that Dynamic Wave routing requires a much smaller time step than the other methods of flow routing.
The time step used to calculate runoff hydrographs.
The time interval for reporting of computed results.

The minimum value allowed for a conduit's slope. If zero (the default) then no minimum is imposed (although SWMM uses a lower limit on elevation drop of 0.001 ft (0.00035 m) when computing a conduit slope).
The minimum surface area to be used at nodes when computing changes in water depth. If you enter 0, then the default value of 12.566 square feet is used.

The time step artificially lengthen conduits so that they meet the Courant stability criterion under full-flow conditions (i.e., the travel time of a wave will not be smaller than the specified conduit lengthening time step). As this value is decreased, fewer conduits will require lengthening. A value of 0 means that no conduits will be lengthened.
When the difference in computed head at each node between successive trials is below this value the flow solution for the current time step is assumed to have converged.
The maximum allowable number of trials performed each time step to reach convergence when updating hydraulic heads at the conveyance system's nodes.
Select whether or not to use a variable time step, which is computed for each time period to prevent an excessive change in water depth at each node.
When the difference in computed head at each node between successive trials is below this value the flow solution for the current time step is assumed to have converged.
Lets you enter a safety factor (between 10 and 200%) to be applied against the variable time step as automatically derived to preserve the Courant stability criterion.
Specify the integration method to use: Modified Euler or Picard Iterations (a method of successive approximations).
Defines how the inertial terms in the St. Venant momentum equation will be handled.
Selects the basis used to determine when supercritical flow occurs in a conduit.
Select which method to be used to handle surcharge conditions. Extran is based on the original SWMM methods, whereas Slot uses a Preissmann slot methodology.
